On your second question:

> My second question :
> 
> When I use NEAT for m=
any generations (2000, for instance), I get
> bigger and bigger networks
> =
(http://webia.lip6.fr/~mouret/nn_cartpole_neat.pdf). This seems
> logical s=
ince NEAT does not any node removing operator. I'm trying 
to
> reduce the =
add_node and add_connection probabilities but I think I
> should stop the e=
volution sometimes.
> =3D> When should I end the evolution ? Considering th=
at I'm trying to
> compare NEAT to some other neuro-evolution methods, I'd =
like to use
> the same number of generations to be as fair as possible.
> 
=

In problems like pole balancing, usually the experiment is ended 
once it =
solves the problem, which usually means balancing a pole for 
some minimum =
number of time steps and/or passing a generalization 
test.  In other words=
, there is a success criterion, and once it's 
passed, the run ends.  

How=
ever, NEAT has an interesting way of improving by minute 
increments almost=
 indefinitely if you simply leave it running.  
Sometimes, for example, you=
 may find that after 500 generations of 
stagnation there is a sudden 0.01 =
improvement in fitness.  This 
phenomenon is due in part of complexificatio=
n, which means that the 
search is never real "over" because every new conn=
ections means that 
a new space opens up that has not yet been explored.  S=
o new 
opporunities keep popping into existence.  Slight nonlinearities 
in=
troduced by sigmoids can also tweak a solution every-so-slightly 
towards i=
mprovement.  Sometimes, all these tiny improvements 
acccumulate to make a =
very large network.

On the other hand, sometimes a particular species may =
become bloated 
with excess structure (though the real question is whether =
*all* 
species are similarly bloated).  In such a case, Colin Green and 
ot=
hers have shown reason to believe that pruning is warranted.

ken
